citation.article-title: Legionella adelaidensis, a new species isolated from cooling tower water.

p.s: Description of Legionella adelaidensis sp. nov.
Legionella adelaidensis (a.del.aid.en'sis N.L. fem. adj. adelaidensis, coming from Adelaide, Australia)
Legionella adelaidensis is a gram-negative rod with a single polar flagellum.
Its cellular fatty acids are predominantly branch chained.
It is positive in reactions for catalase and gelatin liquefaction and requires cysteine for growth.
It is negative for nitrate reduction, oxidase, urease, hippurate hydrolysis, Î²-lactamase, autofluorescence, and acid production from D-glucose.
Antiserum prepared against strain 1762-AUS-E is negative in the slide agglutination test against all heterologous species and serogroups.
The type strain of L. adelaidensis is 1762-AUS-E (ATCC 49625).
It has a guanine-plus-cytosine content of 40 mol%.
It was isolated from cooling tower water.
